The current test cases , I think, would be quite hard for reverse mode. Perhaps just adding/changing one or two test cases as a hint will make it work better – something like "KNOT"=1, "OTONKN"=2, etc.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think it's a nice and simple puzzle, but perhaps should make the input only uppercase or only lowercase to make it a little less annoying to solve. My solution:

import math
knots = input().lower()
print(math.ceil((knots*2).count('knot')/2) + math.ceil((knots[::-1]*2).count('knot')/2))

Thanks  though I'm a bit miffed at the reject - not too sure what you mean here?
It's meant to be a quick fun clash, nothing too difficult and opens up some shortest in languages such as perl.

I'm hoping the title will give that away assuming it is given in reverse mode, and the 0O BABY test case should give this away as the result is 1 as is the round the bend, combined with the first two test cases should provide enough information to get this? I've seen some aweful reverses with almost impossible solutions unless you've visited them a second or third time around!

Sorry my translate from the web!

I don't remember ever seeing the title in reverse mode, I believe it is hidden too – please correct me if I'm just blinded by the tension in CoC, XD.
But the stub generator input will get passed through to reverse mode now that I had seen a tell-tale auto code in the wild (not sure if this is intended?). So yeah, the variable naming and "write knots" should be enough as a hint. Also considering that the puzzle by itself shouldn't be too hard to code, I shall retract my concerns!

I mean that finding a substring a way too simple operation, even on a rolled buffer. 

In "reverse" mode, the tests may help to find what is the answer. First test should be KNOTKNOT, Second test TONK, third test should allow to understand that the buffer is rolled, and so on
